body: ping @tqchen  Can we merge this PR?
cc @vinx13 @merrymercy would be great if you can help comment and review
@icemelon9 could you also help review and merge it?
Thanks @wweic
This PR has been merged. Thanks for hardworking @umangyadav

@MarisaKirisame I experimented with changing `TensorType` to take `TypeVar` to mimic a type function, then we will need to add a new code path in type inference to handle this kind of generic type, in addition to existing generic type logic. That would be a big change and requires broader discussion. cc @jroesch @zhiics @tqchen @icemelon9 

Meanwhile I have added a tiny infrastructure to prelude to generate all tensor array ops for each dtype. Basically each op is just written once, and we specialize it for each dtype.
Approve for now, ideally, it would be great if we can have a transform::Legalize() that users can use which is invariant from any dialect. So we don't have to change the API as we add more dialect.
@anijain2305 specifically, it would be great if we advocate transform::Legalize API while somehow hide qnn::Legalize API(perhaps in a private header)

Thanks @tqchen I agree that an ideal transform::Legalize() will be cleaner. Once we have one dialects, I think we will have more clarity about the requirements and design choices. Lets revisit it then.

@zhiics Can you also please review once and assign it to yourself?
Okay. I will merge it for now. We can consider and probably refactor it somehow once there are more dialects come into play.
@icemelon9 @yzhliu @kevinthesun I think we've probably forgotten this PR.
Ping @llyfacebook A gentle ping :) Please let me know your thoughts about this.
Is this ready for review?
@junrushao1994 yes
@bindog Thanks, this is merged
This is something that I am not sure about. I do think a better way would be to support general broadcast semantics, because users could reply on it instead of bias add

Yes, I agree. I don't like this either. This is restrictive only to bias_add. More concerning is that this is sort of leaky, creating dependency between two passes that are far apart. I will close this one.

The alternate one is more generic - #4040 and improves AlterOpLayout braodcast support.
It works for broadcast ops, instead of bias_add. It inserts expand_dims while transforming the layout.
I also prefer the one in #4040 and with that it seems we can directly remove this CanonicalizeOps pass.
@MarisaKirisame might be a flaky case, can you restart the ci?

> @yzhliu Yeah, I actually thought about replacing it as well. But I ended up skipping it because it looks there is not much difference. I think we probably want to keep compact memory as much as possible because auto broadcast will bring in the if_then_else guard which may not as performant as the compact version. How do you think?

so it won't work for those ops written in hybrid script, right?
@yzhliu Thanks. Removed the binding in hybrid script as it will go through `lower` anyway.
@vinx13 I will restart it right now. Just FYI I also got the same error last time.

Very welcome work @Hzfengsy ! 

> we must relayout before launching the kernel

Does this imply that we'll need to alter the layout of the operators in Relay/NNVM if we want to use tensorization in GPUs as we already do for x86 schedules that use AVX512 (NCHWc), an VTA's tensor core (NCHWnc).
@MarisaKirisame you can try increasing rtol of the failing test
Closing this. #4040 covers this.

Nice to see other folks working on adding TensorCore support into TVM, we have also been working on enhancing TVM to incorporate TensorCore schedule support. 
If my understanding is correct, @Hzfengsy your solution is based on extending TVM's intrinsic while our solution put most of the complexity into TVM IR passes so that at python code level, we don't need to consider too much about TensorCore stuffs, rather the TVM core will take care of most of the TensorCore pattern recognition and schedule customization work, such as col-major/row-major pattern recognition and etc.

@minmin.sun may provide more comments. 

Thanks
cc @Laurawly

Given #3971 got merged, this PR is the only missing piece for reading pre-quantized TFLite models.

Reviews will be greatly appreciated - @jackwish  @apivovarov @zhiics @shoubhik  @tqchen @yzhliu @u99127
A cycle of computing graph in TVM is not expected. And this bug is introduced by `FuseOps` pass.
@tmoreau89 Exactly! For now, we use the NCHWnc layout, the same layout with VTA.

@Hzfengsy Sure, we will show the code as well as a sample schedule very soon. It's being under internal review now. As you will see, the schedule for TensorCore CodeGen looks no different than a normal matmul schedule for GPU. Everything is done in IR passes including matrix_a/matrix_b/accumulator recognition, row/col_major recgnition as @yangjunpro mentioned, thread index unification within a warp for tensorcore operations, loop scaling etc..
@vinx13 it now work.

the more principled fixed is to not look into PrimitiveFunc. Now in Hindsight, PrimitiveFunc should just has their own AST node instead of sharing it with Func - they have completely seprate semantic where one mean RelayFunction and one mean TVM Function.

LGTM.
note that you *should not* pass in a graph to DCE. We only intend for it to support tree form. In general, all the high level analysis/pass (pointer analysis, partial eval, dead code elimination, ad) all assume the input is in tree form.

Just to clarify:

> There is two function, loss and infer, which one calculate loss and gradient, and one just does infer.

Do you mean that there are two modes, training and inference, so that there are multiple entry points in relay Module?
Can we have a more detailed example to help clarify this issue?

And also:

>  'compile then execute' is not enough for all the deep learning workload. For example, using our partial evaluator to specialize training/validation/testing data mean we must compile only after we had loaded all the data.

So in DL, common practice is that we specify the input shape in an ad-hoc way. Particularly, in MNIST, we know that our input is in shape `(batch_size, 784)`. For more complicated workloads, like models containing complicated control flow. I don't really think loading all the data would suffice. Probably compilation should happen in basic block level if say the IR is in CFG (so you need jit)

# TVM Monthly - September 2019
https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/tvm-monthly-september-2019
@soiferj Thanks. It is merged
sgtm

@junrushao1994 yes, that is what I mean, inference mode and training mode, each mode compiled to one function.
we do the partial evaluator primarily for partially evaluating the control flow w.r.t data. Other framework also does this, but they require manual loop unrolling
@MarisaKirisame Do you mean you want the training loop itself to be part of Relay?

No. suppose I have a treelstm. Now normally, I cannot do any operator fusion/batching, because of control flow everywhere. Using the partial eval on batches of training data individually will solve this problem.

However, that require the ability to create multiple entry (one entry per batch). If we also want to use relay for any form of jit, we must be able to interleave running relay/adding more definitions to a relay module.
I see. So for mnist, there is no such issue; but for treelstm, it is true that we are not able to do more optimization if we don't do code replication.

Let's get back to the original topic, which is broader imo.

First of all, depending on your scenario, incremental compilation may be doable or not, like on edge devices where space is only allowed for tvm runtime, not compiler.

Then, I am actually in favor of incremental compilation, or some profiling guided stuff. I do think that it is inevitable for training, especially when people are increasingly interested in more flexible models.

However, it is not quite clear for me whether we need multiple entries. Can we do better than a single module? Maybe @comaniac can offer some thoughts.

BTW, in the treelstm example, i am curious why we need a training/dev/test-data-dependent full code replication? It seems to be possible to do that partially so that it could be more controllable.
@yzhliu @vinx13 @tqchen @zhiics @ZihengJiang Ping for review. I am done from my side.

@junrushao1994 we unroll the control flow to be more efficient.
maybe multiple module can work, but there cant be code sharing between multiple ones.
my point is that we don't have to do full data-dependent unrolling, but unroll a deterministic 4 steps or 10 steps to make it data independent
Why is it assumed a tree form? I can see that the base class `ExprVisitor` also use the `visit_counter_` to make sure all the expr are visited once.
@yaochengji because what does it mean for a graph form program to have scope and effect?

@junrushao1994 it is only possible for lstm. for treelstm if you do it it will blow up exponentially, and lots of time will be spend on testing the match on all the cases - unless some tricks are used (for example, a decision tree for pattern matching instead of linear)
still, this doesnt allow batching for treelstm

> Ping @llyfacebook A gentle ping :) Please let me know your thoughts about this.
Thanks for raising the issue, @anijain2305. 
"When I change the test, it starts failing.", You mean you just set the inequal out_channel and in_channel? I will try to reproduce the issue. Can we double check the performance on X86?

Yes, the test failed when I had different input and output channels.

You can also reproduce the issue by using the test case in this PR and uncommenting the dispatch to nhwc pack compute.

@MarisaKirisame but I think since using a `visit_counter` to guarantee the complexity is a default behavior in `ExprVisitor`, it should not be dropped in `CalcDep `.

cc @icemelon9
@kevinthesun @FrozenGene can you please review this patch
you can still has it. I just mean you should not pass graph in.

I have not tried to run tracker on jupyter, perhaps @merrymercy @vinx13 can comment. from a quick look at the errors. The main reason seems to due to the "Connection time out", then the event handling loop tried to add the bad socket into its set of sockets(which leads to bad file descriptor)

By default we have one entry point("main") but there is nothing preventing us from calling into other compiled functions as long as they are exposed as PackedFunc. So we should have already supported that.

The incremental compilation is supported in the level of modules, which means we can have one module that get compiled, and as you have additional needs, generate new modules that can then get compiled.

Given that the topic of discussion does not yet have a actionable item, i would recommend we move the discussion to https://discuss.tvm.ai/ (examples like https://discuss.tvm.ai/c/rfc)

@anijain2305 Thank you for adding this! I have the same issue when trying to internally transfer conv2d to NCHWc layout for tf model.

One question is that can we directly use BinaryBroadcastLayout for bias_add?

It might be issues with your network setup. Local runner is equivalent to RPC runner with tracker and server running on localhost. You can try using RPC mode by starting RPC tracker and server with your custom address (e.g. `0.0.0.0`)
@MarisaKirisame https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/3925/files#r330840227
After discussion, I think this change is necessary. LGTM
ping @tqchen  @ZihengJiang
We can test once heterogeneous execution is added. Or we can still pass a dict to VM, but it seems not to be good test anyway.
Yes, it's not easy to test this unless we have a performance test.

Could you rebase the pr against the latest master?

sure. It will increase the robustness of the DCE.

Thanks!

Thanks for bringing up the problem. it should be an issue with git submodule, the dependency is in a submodule. you can resolve by recursively cloning the repo. For follow up questions, please open a new on discuss.tvm.ai
@yurivict you can follow the build instruction here: https://docs.tvm.ai/install/from_source.html
Please add a test case
@vinx13 Done.
The automated release detection system shows that 0.5 is the latest release and packages need to be updated to 0.5, while you do active development in 0.4 branch.

The error might be caused by incorrect arch setting. You can use 
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/cffb4fba03ea582417e2630bd163bca773756af6/python/tvm/contrib/nvcc.py#L218-L238
to conditionally skip the test on ci.

Instead of adding these functions, directly overriding CUDA codegen rules for `half` might be preferred since we also want to deal with `half2` and avoid repetition
Adding @yuluny2 to also review the PR.
Thanks @yaochengji  @MarisaKirisame this is merged
Would it be easy to extend your gemm schedule into a schedule for BatchMatMul? That would help round out the TensorCore story for matrix multiplication.
lgtm
Given that this is an issue of mxnet, please open a new thread there. For questions related to tvm, please open a new thread on https://discuss.tvm.ai/

Thanks for the contribution. One of the things we bought up in https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/discuss-all-in-one-build-api-and-pass-api-composability/4064 is to reduce the amount of options in an All-in-one API.

In particular, because print is one feature, and we might want some other related features, it would be great if we can add a trace_callback API, that get called before or after every pass, and we can do

```python
with relay.PassContext(trace=relay.transform.PrintIR()):
    mypass
```

We can open an RFC for further discussions
@umangyadav please also comment on whether we have addressed the issue of adding the guard conditions back(besides improving the bound deducer).
Thanks @ndl
Thanks @MarisaKirisame @soiferj @weberlo @anijain2305
Thanks @mbarrett97 !

Thank @tmoreau89 for the comments.
There is no stable GPU scheduling yet, so we can't show the GPU version.

@tmoreau89 
In my personal testing, TVM runs faster than MxNet but has similar speed with PyTorch.
Also, the inference time is very short (under 30ms) for each iteration.
I'm not sure whether it's fair to show the runtime comparison.

I had the impression that this way of doing it would be uncontroversial and simple, though seems I got that wrong and of course it has to fit the overall design of TVM. I'll note that this feature is not equivalent to, and I think better than, inserting PrintIR after every pass. Googling for "tvm rfc" didn't yield clear results on whether the way to do an RFC is to post an issue to Github with [RFC] in the title or to send an email to discuss.tvm.ai with that in the title, since I found both cases. Please advise. Thank you.

(zhiics@ advised that an email will be fine, so going with that)

For general design discussions, we can just open a new RFC thread on https://discuss.tvm.ai/. For features that are actionable, open a new RFC thread on github issues and we can act on it. Thanks for bringing up the problem of lack of docs for RFC, perhaps we should enrich the developer docs.

Another comment - Currently, QNN includes headers (code) from Relay. I tried to make it as uni-directional as possible. However, this will create bi-directional code inclusion (which might be ok). Therefore, it is worth thinking if we should put FixedPointMultiply in some header in Relay, which QNN can now read from.

As a side note(we can move the following discussion to the RFC thread). I understand the useful-ness of this API, just wanted to see if we can bring it to be more generic.

Imagine in a world where we want to add additional options such as save IRs to the files, collect the IRs so we can introspect them etc. Instead of adding an option to PassContext for each of these features, would be great if we can design a trace callback option that we can just pass in different variants. Whether we should pass in PrintIR pass or other callbacks can be discussed.

@zhiics there is nothing special for tuple. It fail for other cases too - in mergefromto, the groups and functions that will generate is already defined, and it must merge at that point, or stuff will goes out of scope.
@tqchen What kind of test case is in your mind?
